articles.name: Failures and Phish-prone Percentages
articles.title: Failures and Phish-prone Percentages
articles.body:
During a phishing campaign, your users will receive Phishing Security Tests (PST). Based on if they fail or pass the phishing security test, they will receive a Phish-prone Percentage. Users with a low Phish-prone Percentage are less likely to fall for real phishing attacks than those with a higher Phish-prone Percentage. If you’re interested in learning more about PST, see our What is a Phishing Security Test (PST) and How Does it Work? article.

What Is a Failure?

If a user interacts with the email in an unsafe way, that action is a failure and the user fails that test. Users can have multiple failures from a PST during a phishing campaign. In order from most to least severe, the different types of failures are listed below:

  • Entering data on a landing page
  • Entering personal information in a callback phishing call
  • Enabling a macro on an attachment
  • Replying to the simulated phishing email
  • Opening an attachment
  • Scanning a QR Code
  • Calling the number and entering the callback code in a callback phishing email
  • Clicking the embedded link

How Phish-prone Percentage Is Calculated

A Phish-prone Percentage is the percentage of employees that are prone to click on a phishing link. It differs from a Phish-failure Percentage since it tracks the exact way a user fails. It is possible for a user to have many failures on one email and receive a Phish-prone Percentage that goes over 100 percent. For example, if a user opens an email, clicks on the link, and opens the attachment, they have two failures and one failed phishing test. As a result, this user will have a 200 percent personal Phish-prone Percentage, because the user failed two times in one test.

A higher personal Phish-prone Percentage indicates that the individual user may be more vulnerable to an email-borne social engineering attack. If a user opens a simulated phishing email and has many failures, then they are failing to spot red flags. Knowing the number and types of failures can help determine what training the user needs.

Campaign Phish-prone Percentage

A phishing campaign creates a Phish-prone Percentage from the number of total failures divided by the total number of emails delivered in that campaign.

If 100 people received emails, and 52 of them clicked a link in the email that would mean 52 percent of them failed. If eight of those 52 people also entered data into the landing page, that would increase the Phish-prone Percentage for that campaign to 60 percent.

articles.name: Scam of the Week Message Overview
articles.title: Scam of the Week Message Overview
articles.body:
The Scam of the Week is a weekly message written by KnowBe4. The message summarizes a recent real-world scam and provides tips on how to stay safe from similar scams. To send the message to your users, you can use our user messaging feature to create and send a recurring message.

If you want your users to be able to view any Scam of the Week sent to them, we encourage you to set it up as a message. Every message will remain listed in the KSAT admin console under Users > Messages and in the Messages tab of the Learner Experience (LX). When you send a Scam of the Week message to your users, the message will remain in the Messages tab of the LX until you hide it.

Tip:If you want to send a message with a specific theme, we recommend using the Security Hints and Tips message. These messages cover similar themes to the Scam of the Week, but they avoid mentioning specific events.

Set Up a Scam of the Week Message

Users will be able to view the Scam of the Week on the Messages tab of the Learner Experience (LX). You can customize the frequency you send these messages, and you have the option to send a copy of the message to each user via email. For general information about messages, see our User Messaging Guide.

Note:Scam of the Week messages are now available in 34 languages for better localization support. To access this new feature, admins must enable the Enable Localized Training Notifications toggle in Account Settings > Training > Learner Experience.

To create a Scam of the Week message, follow the steps below:

  1. From your KnowBe4 console, navigate to Users > Messages.
  2. Click the +Create New Message button at the top-right corner of the page.
  3. Select Scam of the Week.
  4. Customize your settings. For more information about each setting, see the screenshot and list below:

    1. Message Type: Select Scam of the Week from the menu.
    2. Frequency: Choose how often Scam of the Week messages should be sent.
    3. Send to: To send the Scam of the Week to your entire organization, select All Users. To only send the Scam of the Week to part of your organization, select Specific Groups and choose one or more groups from the drop-down menu.
    4. Message Delivery Date: In this field, select when you would like to send your message.
      Note:When using a frequency other than One-time, each subsequent message will be sent on the day of the week that was selected.
    5. Also send this message as an email: Select this check box to send a copy of the Scam of the Week message to each user via email. This message will still be listed on the Messages tab of the LX.
      Tip:Emails sent using the User Messaging feature are not tracked and will not be included in any message-related data.
    6. Use Custom Sender Information: Enable this option to customize the sender's name and email address. The email address must match one of the allowed domains on your account.
    7. Show Preview: This option displays a preview of the Scam of the Week message to be sent. If you want to edit this message, go to Manage Templates, then clone it from the System Templates. Edit it and select it using the My Templates section when creating a message.
    8. Schedule Message: Review your selections, then click Schedule Message. You’ll see a preview of that week’s Scam of the Week message.

articles.name: Defend - URL Decoding
articles.title: Defend - URL Decoding
articles.body:
Defend rewrites URLs in inbound emails to scan the linked content for security risks, using linguistic and contextual analysis.

You may need to decode these URLs to view them in their original form without visiting the link.

To do this:

  1. Access your Defend console.
  2. Navigate to URL Rewriting / Decode URL Decode.
  3. Paste the encoded Defend URL into the field.
  4. The original link is displayed.

Decoding Double-Protected Links

Some mail systems, such as Microsoft 365 SafeLinks, already have a feature that rewrites URLs. The Defend-encoded URL may be created using this rewritten link.

  1. You will need to decode the original link using a suitable tool. There are options available online for decoding these links.
  2. Once decoded, you can paste this into the Defend URL Decode tool using the steps above. The original link will then be displayed.

articles.name: KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
By default, your KnowBe4 Security Awareness Training (KSAT) console is automatically integrated with your SecurityCoach product. This integration allows you to use phishing data from KSAT to create real-time coaching campaigns in SecurityCoach.

To view your integration, log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations. Under the Active Integrations section, you’ll see the KSAT vendor tile.

Click Edit on the KSAT vendor tile to view the detection rules for this integration or delete the integration. 

To review your KSAT detection rules and use them in a real-time coaching campaign, click Review Detection Rules. For more information, see our Real-Time Coaching Campaigns Guide.

To delete this integration, click Delete Integration.

articles.name: Bill 96 French Language Requirement in the Province of Québec, Canada
articles.title: Bill 96 French Language Requirement in the Province of Québec, Canada
articles.body:
In May of 2022, Québec’s National Assembly passed Bill 96 to promote the use of the French language in the Province of Québec. Taking effect in June 2023, the law requires, among other things, that all policies and training materials assigned to employees within the province be provided in the French language. 

KnowBe4 recognizes the value of providing content in the language in which employees are most comfortable learning, not just in Canada, but throughout the world. To that end, we have supported Canadian French (Québécois) as a major language for five years (See our Language Support List) and we continue to provide materials in French where it is culturally appropriate. We also localized much of this content (by providing local voices and examples in Canadian French) where it makes sense to do so. At the time of this writing, there are 486 pieces of content in our ModStore available in French, and also 475 pieces of content that are localized in Canadian French. 

End users may select their preferred language in our Learner Experience (LX), so we highly recommend offering these options when assigning any content to users in the region. While there are many pieces of training content that are dubbed with a French voice, some are only captioned based on the context of the training content. We are committed to working with local organizations to identify French content that would benefit from being fully localized.  As an example of our commitment, we are continuing to dub seasons 3 through 5 of The Inside Man in French (in addition to seasons 1 and 2, which are already fully dubbed) and hope to have them available in time for cybersecurity awareness month (October 2023).  We always welcome feedback, so if you believe a piece of training content requires translation or localization to meet the requirements of the bill, please feel free to reach out to us. 

KnowBe4 is committed to providing the highest quality security awareness and compliance content in the world. Our global team is focused on providing local content options for all of our customers. Keeping Canadians safe from cybercrime, as well as compliant with laws and regulations, is an important mission of KnowBe4. We will continue adding more content to our library to meet the needs of our growing base of valued customers and partners.

articles.name: Integrate Drata with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.title: Integrate Drata with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.body:
KnowBe4’s integration with Drata combines KSAT training results with the Drata platform, which automates the evidence collection process for security awareness training. Once the integration is complete, Drata will automatically recognize KnowBe4 as your default security awareness training provider. You can use this integration to track the training results for each KSAT training campaign synced with Drata.

Prerequisites

Before you can connect Drata to KSAT, you must meet the following requirements:

  1. You must know the API Token and the server location for your account.
    Note: For the API Token, use the Reporting API Token found in your KSAT Account Settings. For more information, see the API section of our KSAT Account Settings: Account Integrations article.
  2. You must have a training campaign in your KSAT console that is in Created, Pending, Active, or Closed status. Data from deleted campaigns cannot be imported to Drata.

Connecting Your KSAT Console to the Drata Platform

To connect your KSAT console to the Drata platform, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Drata admin console.
  2. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, click your company’s logo and click Connections from the menu.
  3. Find KnowBe4 in the Security Training section and click Connect. When you click Connect, the Connection Instructions pop-up window will open.
  4. In the Connection Instructions pop-up window, enter your API Token and select the Server location.
  5. Click Connect your KnowBe4 Account to open the Manage Campaigns pop-up window.
  6. In the Manage Campaigns pop-up window, select your training campaigns from the drop-down menu. These campaigns will be integrated with Drata to sync personnel activity.
    Important:If your users are enrolled in multiple campaigns, they’ll need to pass all the campaigns you selected in the previous step to be compliant in Drata.
  7. Click Save. 
  8. Find KnowBe4 in the My Connections section to confirm that your KSAT console was connected to the Drata platform.

Verifying Your Training Provider Settings

When you connect your KSAT console to the Drata platform, Drata will automatically set KnowBe4 as your training provider. To verify your settings, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Drata admin console.
  2. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, click your company’s logo and click Internal Security from the menu.
  3. In the Annual Security Awareness Training section, confirm that the Use KnowBe4 for security awareness training radio button is selected. If this radio button is not selected, you can select it and click Update to change the setting.

User Experience

After integration, the Drata platform will prompt your new users to complete their training in their KnowBe4 accounts. As your users complete their training, a KnowBe4-branded window will display on their devices. The users’ training progress will be tracked to provide you with daily updates. When a user completes their assigned training, the Drata platform will generate a downloadable completion certificate.

articles.name: How to Export Questionnaires
articles.title: How to Export Questionnaires
articles.body:
In your KCM GRC Vendor Risk Management module, you can create and configure questionnaires to send to the vendors or third parties your organization works with. If you would like to save configured or completed questionnaires for your records, you can export them as CSV files.

For information about creating and configuring a questionnaire, see our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article. To learn how to export configured questionnaires and completed questionnaires, see the sections below. 

Exporting Configured Questionnaires

After you configure a questionnaire, you can export a CSV file that contains information about the questionnaire. Then, you can download the CSV file to your device.

To export a configured questionnaire, follow the steps below:

  1. From your navigation panel, navigate to Vendor Management > Questionnaires.
  2. From the Name column, select the questionnaire that you would like to export. 
  3. In the Questionnaire Versions section of the page, click the Export button.
  4. Open the file download. If you would like, you can save the file to your device.

Information in the Configured Questionnaire CSV File

The CSV file will contain information about the questionnaire you configured.

For information about the headers that are included in the CSV file, see the table below:

Column Header Description
section

If the question is from a system template, the fields in this column will display the name of the section that the question is from. If the question is a custom question that you added or imported into the questionnaire, this column will display Custom. 
question

The fields in this column will display each question in the questionnaire.

Important: Custom questions with answer options that are in the multiple choice or checkbox formats will have multiple rows in the CSV file. Each answer option for the question will include a row. 
type

The fields in this column will display the type of answer option that the question uses, including Yes/ No/ N/A, multi for multiple choice, Free form for free form text, or checkbox for check boxes. 
answer_options

answer_options: The fields in this column will display each answer option available for the question.

For information about the how answer options will display based on answer type, see the list below:

  • If the type is free form, the field will be blank.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the question will have multiple rows in the CSV file because each answer option will display on a separate row. 
  • If the type is checkbox, the question will have multiple rows in the CSV file because each answer option will display on a separate row. 
  • If the type is Yes/ No/ N/A, the field will display Yes/ No/ N/A.
is_correct

The fields in this column will display the correct answer for the question.

For information about how the correct answers will display based on answer type, see the list below:

  • If the type is free form, the field will be blank.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the question will have multiple rows in the CSV file because each answer option will display on a separate row. The row that contains the correct answer option will display Selected.
  • If the type is checkbox, this column will be blank because the question can have multiple correct answers. 
  • If the type is Yes/ No/ N/A, the field will display the correct answer, such as Yes.
how_to_answer

The fields in this column will display how the vendor should answer the question.

For information about how the vendor should answer based on answer type, see the list below:

  • If the type is free form, the field will display Free form.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the field will display Please choose one.
  • If the type is checkbox, the field will display Please choose all that apply.
  • If the type is Yes/ No / N/A, the field will display Please choose one. 
score

The fields in this column will display the total number of points a vendor can receive for the question. 

Important: If the question type is multiple choice or checkbox, the score will be repeated on each row that exists for the question.
is_informational

If the question is marked informational, the fields in this column will display TRUE. 

Exporting Completed Questionnaires

After a vendor completes a questionnaire, you can export a CSV file that contains information about the questionnaire, including the vendor's answers. Then, you can download the CSV file to your device.

To export a completed questionnaire, follow the steps below:

  1. From your navigation panel, navigate to Vendor Management > Vendors.
  2. From the Name column, select a vendor. When you select a vendor, you'll be taken to the Vendor Details page.
  3. Select the Assigned Questionnaires subtab.
  4. Click the Export button next to the questionnaire that you would like to export.
    Note:The Export button will only display next to questionnaires that are in the Pending Review, In Review, or Reviewed statuses.
  5. Open the file download. If you would like, you can save the file to your device.

Information in the Completed Questionnaire CSV File

The CSV file will contain information about the questionnaire that the vendor completed, including the vendor's questionnaire answers.

For information about the headers that are included in the CSV file, see the table below:

Column Header Description
question

The fields in this column will display each question in the questionnaire.

Important: Custom questions with answer options that are in the multiple choice or checkbox formats will have multiple rows in the CSV file. Each answer option for the question will include a row.
informational

If the question is marked as informational, the fields in this column will display TRUE. For more information about informational questions, see our How to Create and Configure Questionnaires article.
type

The fields in this column will display the type of answer option that the question uses, including Yes/ No/ N/A, multi for multiple choice, Free form for free form text, or checkbox for check boxes.
answer_options

The fields in this column will display each answer option available for the question.

For information about how answer options will display based on answer type, see the list below:

  • If the type is free form, the field will be blank.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the question will have multiple rows because each answer option will display on a separate row. 
  • If the type is checkbox, the question will have multiple rows because each answer option will display on a separate row. 
  • If the type is Yes/ No/ N/A, the field will display Yes/ No/ N/A.
weight This column only applies to checkbox questions. The fields in this column will display the weight of each answer option. For example, some options may have a weight of .5 points, while some might have a weight of 0 points. The weight for each answer option will be listed on separate lines within a row.
correct_answer

The fields in the column will display the correct answer for the question.

For information about how the correct answers will display based on answer type, see the list below:

  • If the type is free form, the field will be blank.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the question will have multiple rows because each answer option will display on a separate row. The row that contains the correct answer option will display Selected.
  • If the type is checkbox, the field will be blank because the question can have multiple correct answers.
  • If the type is Yes/ No/ N/A, the field will display the correct answer, such as Yes.
vendor_answer

The fields in this column will display the vendor's answer to the question.

For information about how the vendor's answer will display based on answer type, see the list below: 

  • If the type is free form, the field will display the vendor's answer.
  • If the type is multiple choice, the question will have multiple rows because each answer option will display on a separate row. The row that contains the answer option that the vendor selected will display Selected.
  • If the type is checkbox, the question will have multiple rows because each answer option will display on a separate row. Because checkbox questions allow vendors to select multiple answers, the field will display Selected next to each answer option that the vendor selected.
  • If the type is Yes/ No/ N/A, the field will display the answer that the vendor selected.
max_score The fields in this column will display the maximum number of points that the vendor could have received for the question. 
current_score

If you modified the original score that the vendor received for the question, the fields in this column will display the updated score. If you did not modify the original score, the fields in this column will be blank. 
comments If the vendor added a comment for the question, the fields in this column will display the comment. 
issue

If an issue was created for the question, the fields in this column will display the issue description.
issue_status

If you created an issue for the question, the fields in this column will display the current status of the issue. The issue statuses are Open, Pending, and Closed.

articles.name: Engage Users During Cybersecurity Awareness Month
articles.title: Engage Users During Cybersecurity Awareness Month
articles.body:
Observed every October, Cybersecurity Awareness Month provides an opportunity to raise awareness and improve your organization's security culture. You can teach and encourage your users all month long by following the Weekly Planners found in our Cybersecurity Awareness Month Resource Kits.

You can find links to our available resource kits in the table below:

Subscription Level Resource Kit Link

Gold and Platinum

 Cybersecurity Awareness Month Resource Kit
Diamond Cybersecurity Awareness Month Resource Kit

In your KSAT console, you’ll find two new landing pages and four new phishing templates, which have been localized into all of our supported languages. These resources relate to the topic covered in each week of the Weekly Planner. We recommend using these landing pages and phishing templates together for a cohesive and engaging learning experience. To increase participation with your users, we recommend enabling the Leaderboard. For more information, see the Learner Experience (LX) section of our KnowBe4 Console Account Settings: Training article.

Tip: Gamification helps make training fun and engaging while enabling your users to retain more information. For more information on how to gamify your security awareness training, see our Gamification Options PDF guide.

To learn more about these resources and how to share them with your users, see the section below.

Cybersecurity Awareness Month Landing Pages and Phishing Templates

For Cybersecurity Awareness Month, we created four phishing templates and two new landing pages. Each phishing template is an example of a common cybersecurity threat, such as social engineering and malicious URLs. Each landing page teaches users how to protect themselves and your organization from these threats.

If you would like to preview the Cybersecurity Awareness Month phishing templates, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to Phishing > Phishing Templates.
  2. Select System Templates.
  3. Copy a title from the list below to search in the search bar on the right side of the page for the phishing template you would like to preview:
    • [[email]] Password Alert (Link) (Spoofs Domain) (Branded)
    • ChatGPT: Your Custom ChatGPT AI Portal is Now Live (Link)
    • Ransomware Scan (Link) (Spoofs Domain) (Branded)
    • Microsoft 365: Your incident has been opened (Link)
  4. Once you find the phishing template, select the eye icon next to the title to preview it.

If you would like to preview Cybersecurity Awareness Month landing pages, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to Phishing > Landing Pages.
  2. Select System Landing Pages. Copy a title from the list below to search in the search bar on the right side of the page for the landing page you would like to preview:
    • Browser Language Detecting: Welcome to the Awareness Arcade
    • Browser Language Detecting: Could this be Game Over?
  3. Once you find the landing page, select the eye icon next to the title to preview it.

These phishing templates and landing pages are designed to be used together in four Phishing Security Tests (PSTs), one for each week of Cybersecurity Awareness Month. To create these PSTs, navigate to the Phishing tab and select + Create Phishing Campaign. Then, select the recommended settings below and customize the campaign as needed.

Tip: For general information about phishing campaigns, see our Create and Manage Phishing Campaigns article.
  1. Template Topics: Select Cybersecurity Awareness Month .

  2. Template Selection: Select Specific Template (Choose one template). Then, select one of the templates listed below. The area below the arrow in the screenshot will show these four templates in a drop-down menu:
    • Week 1: [[email]] Password Alert (Link) (Spoofs Domain) (Branded)
    • Week 2: ChatGPT: Your Custom ChatGPT AI Portal is Now Live (Link)
    • Week 3: Ransomware Scan (Link) (Spoofs Domain) (Branded)
    • Week 4: Microsoft 365: Your incident has been opened (Link)

  3. Landing Page: From the drop-down menu, select the landing page you would like to use:
    • Weeks 1 and 2: Browser Language Detecting: Welcome to the Awareness Arcade
    • Weeks 3 and 4: Browser Language Detecting: Could this be Game Over?
  4. Frequency: Select One-time.
  5. Start Time: To send one PST each week during Cybersecurity Awareness Month, use the corresponding dates listed below:
    • For your week 1 campaign, select October 6, 2025.
    • For your week 2 campaign, select October 13, 2025.
    • For your week 3 campaign, select October 20, 2025.
    • For your week 4 campaign, select October 27, 2025.
  6. Sending Period: Set your campaign to send emails over 3 business days.
  7. Customize the rest of the settings as you would like, then select Create Campaign.
  8. Repeat these steps for each of the four weeks of Cybersecurity Awareness Month

articles.name: Personal Settings Guide
articles.title: Personal Settings Guide
articles.body:
All admins and Security Role users in your KSAT console have access to their own Personal Settings. The Personal Settings page is used to update personal information and preferences such as name, time zone, preferred date and time format, phone number, password, and Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) settings. For more information about how to set up MFA for your account, see our Enable Two-Factor or Multi-Factor Authentication on Your Account article.

Note: If you're an end-user, read the User Profile section of our Learner Support: Navigating the Learner Experience (LX) article or watch our Editing Your Profile video for information on how to access your profile.

Accessing Your Profile

To access your Personal Settings, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Click on your email address in the top-right corner of the page.

  3. From the drop-down menu, click Personal Settings.

Personal Details

In your Personal Details subtab, you can update information such as your name, mobile phone number, MFA settings, and more. For more information, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. First Name: Enter your preferred first name.
  2. Last Name: Enter your preferred last name.
  3. Time Zone: Select your preferred time zone. Your selection will change how timestamps appear to you in the admin console.
  4. Date and time format: Select your preferred date and time format. Your selection will change how dates and times appear to you in the admin console.
  5. Phone Number: Enter your preferred phone number.
  6. Extension: Enter the extension of your preferred phone number, if applicable.
  7. Mobile Phone Number: Enter your preferred mobile phone number.
  8. Multi-factor Authentication: Enable or disable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for your account. For more information, see our Enable Two-Factor or Multi-Factor Authentication on Your Account article.
  9. Change Password: Click this button to change your password.
  10. Log Out of All Sessions: Click this button to log yourself out of all active sessions in the KSAT console.

After making any updates to this page, click Update Profile to save your changes.

Notifications and Alerts

You can use the Notifications and Alerts subtab to manage system notifications and alerts. For more information, see the screenshot and list below:

Note: The SecurityCoach Notification Subscriptions section is only available for customers with a SecurityCoach subscription.

  1. Platform Critical Alerts: Receive critical and time-sensitive notifications for platform updates that may require administrative attention or action. For more information, see our KnowBe4 Platform Notifications article.
  2. SecurityCoach Critical Alerts: Receive alerts and regular reminders when critical SecurityCoach updates are required or a vendor integration fails.
    Important:Critical alerts are always sent in real-time, and reminders about unresolved SecurityCoach critical alerts are sent every three calendar days.
  3. Integration Health: Receive alerts and recommendations for your vendor integrations.
  4. User Management: Receive alerts and recommendations for mapping your users to identifiers and risky activity.
  5. System Detection Rules: Receive alerts about updates to system detection rules.
  6. Campaign Insights: Receive summaries and recommendations for your real-time coaching campaigns.
  7. Notification Frequency: Each category can be customized to send at different regular intervals:
    • Daily: Receive the selected notification every business day at 2:00 p.m. in your organization’s set time zone.
      Note:If 2:00 p.m. is not in your organization’s set business hours, the notification will be sent at the next available business hour. To update your organization’s business days and hours, see our KnowBe4 Console Account Settings: Account Information article.
    • Weekly: Receive the selected notification every Wednesday at 2:00 p.m. in your organization’s set time zone.
      Note:If Wednesday at 2:00 p.m. is not in your organization’s set business hours, the notification will be sent at the next available business hour. To update your organization’s business days and hours, see our KnowBe4 Console Account Settings: Account Information article.
  8. Notification Delivery Method: Select how you would like to receive notifications and alerts. If a problem occurs with a messaging app, notifications will be sent by email.
    Note:To receive notifications using messaging apps, you must first configure the messaging app in your SecurityCoach console. For more information, see our Configuring Delivery Methods articles.

Click Save Changes to confirm and save your updates.

Tip:For your convenience, a Manage Notifications link is included at the bottom of every notification. Selecting the link opens a dedicated page where you can manage your preferences. For security purposes, access to this page expires after 24 hours. You can always manage your notification preferences by using the Notifications and Alerts subtab

articles.name: Scam of the Week Historical List
articles.title: Scam of the Week Historical List
articles.body:
The Scam of the Week email template is a great way to keep your users informed about the newest social engineering scams. Based on content from the KnowBe4 blog, the template is updated and replaced weekly. This article lists the date and title for each Scam of the Week in descending order. For more information on Scam of the Week emails, please see our How to Set Up a "Scam of the Week" Newsletter article.

articles.name: Whitelist in SpamAssassin
articles.title: Whitelist in SpamAssassin
articles.body:
If you're utilizing SpamAssassin's spam filtering, you can whitelist KnowBe4 to allow our simulated phishing test emails and training notifications through to your end users.

Although there is typically not an interface for SpamAssassin, you can edit your custom SpamAssassin config file to add rules allowing KnowBe4's emails through–based on the header and IP address of the phishing tests.

The instructions below are for a third-party software. If you run into issues whitelisting KnowBe4 in SpamAssassin, we recommend reaching out to SpamAssassin for specific instructions. You can also contact our support team whenever you need assistance.

Below you can see the rules you'll want to add. Please make sure to substitute the text in red with our IP addresses. For the most up-to-date list of our IP addresses, please see this article.

Important:This rule set contains lines for both our US and EU IP addresses, you'll only need to include the IPs for the server where your account resides.

header           __KNOWBE4_HEADER               X-PHISHTEST =~ /\bKnowBe4\b/iheader           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_001     Received =~ /\[xx\.xx\.xxx\.xxx\]/header           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_002     Received =~ /\[xx\.xx\.xxx\.xxx\]/header           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_003     Received =~ /\[xx\.xxx\.xxx\.xxx\]/meta              __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US              (__KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_001 || __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_002 || __KNOWBE4_RCVD_US_003)

header           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_001      Received =~ /\[xx\.xx\.xxx\.xxx\]/header           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_002      Received =~ /\[xx\.xx\.xxx\.xxx\]/header           __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_003      Received =~ /\[xxx\.xxx\.xxx\.xxx\]/meta              __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU               (__KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_001 || __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_002 || __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU_003)

meta              KNOWBE4                                    (__KNOWBE4_HEADER && (__KNOWBE4_RCVD_US || __KNOWBE4_RCVD_EU))

describe         KNOWBE4                                   Mail is from KnowBe4score              KNOWBE4                                   -20.0

Note:After following this article, we recommend setting up a test phishing campaign to 1-2 users to ensure your whitelisting was successful. As a last resource, we suggest reaching out to your service provider for assistance. Visit here for an email template you can send to your service provider.
Tip:To ensure that you have whitelisted correctly, see our How to Verify You Have Whitelisted KnowBe4 Correctly article.

articles.name: KB4Diag Tool Guide
articles.title: KB4Diag Tool Guide
articles.body:
The KB4Diag tool is an executable file that KnowBe4's support team uses to automatically gather issue-specific files, including event and security logs and other files for troubleshooting. The support team requests that users run this tool when encountering issues with RanSim.

Note:When using the KB4Diag tool for RanSim, application logs need to be added separately. To find the application logs, please locate the folder where the product is installed. For more information, see our RanSim Product Manual.

After you download and run KB4Diag, the tool will gather all relevant files and package the files into a zip file. Then, you can send these files to the support technician from your ticket so that the support technician can view the files. 

Note: If you prefer not to use KB4Diag to locate and gather these files, you can ask our support team which files they need to troubleshoot your issue. Then, you can locate these files manually. 

Installing and Running KB4Diag

After a support technician requests that you run the KB4Diag tool, please follow the instructions below. 

  1. Download the executable file from the link that the support technician included in your ticket.
    Important: You must download the file onto the machine where the affected program is installed.
  2. Navigate to the KB4Diag file in the Downloads folder of your File Explorer.
  3. Double-click the file to run it. 
  4. Click Run in the pop-up window.
  5. Check the box to agree to the End User License Agreement, and click Continue.
  6. After the tool runs, please follow the instructions below.
    1. Run: Click this button to run KB4Diag.
    2. Brief Description of Issue: Add details about the issue you are encountering with the product.
    3. Ticket Product Type: Select RanSim from the drop-down menu.
    4. Ticket Email Address: Enter your preferred email address. This email address does not need to match the email address that you used to submit the support request. 
    5. Ticket ID: Enter the ticket number from your support ticket.
  7. Wait for the scan to complete. The scan can take up to 10 minutes or longer depending on the number of files that the tool gathers.
  8. Locate any files that you want to include in your support ticket by following the steps below. 
    1. Open your File Explorer.
    2. Navigate to ProgramData\KnowBe4\[[Affected Product]]\Support. 
    3. Review the files in the folder above.
    4. Upload any necessary files to your support request. If you are responding to your support request via email, attach any files to the email.

Files That KB4Diag Gathers

When you run KB4Diag, the tool gathers the files below: 

  • Application logs for the affected program
  • Configuration files for the affected program
  • Registry keys for the affected program
  • Last five days of Application Event logs
  • Last five days of System Event logs
  • Last three days of Security Event logs
  • MSInfo ipconfig.txt
  • Files in InstallDir for the affected program
  • List of all currently running processes
  • Data entered into Diagnostics UI

Troubleshooting KB4Diag

When you run KB4Diag, you may encounter the error below:

If you encounter this error, please follow the steps below:

  1. Save the KB4Diag file to your Downloads folder. 
  2. Run the file from its saved location. 

If the steps above do not resolve the error, or if you encounter a different error, please contact the KnowBe4 Support Team.

articles.name: Prevent Microsoft Defender for Office 365 from Rewriting KnowBe4 Phishing Links
articles.title: Prevent Microsoft Defender for Office 365 from Rewriting KnowBe4 Phishing Links
articles.body:
Microsoft Defender for Office 365 feature may cause URLs from our Phishing Security Tests (PSTs) to be rewritten. If you would like, you have the option to exclude these URLs from being rewritten.

If you're looking for information about whitelisting in Microsoft Defender for Office, see our How to Use Advanced Delivery Policies in Microsoft Defender for Office article.

Important:If you aren't excluding any other URLs from being rewritten, exempting only KnowBe4's phish links may help your users identify the links as red flags more easily. Without being rewritten, the URLs may be easier to identify as part of a PST.

To exclude our phish links from being rewritten, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console.
  2. Navigate to the Phishing tab, then select the Domains subtab. This subtab will display a list of our root phish link domains. For more information, see our How to Manage Phish Link Domains article.
    Note:If you don't have access to this subtab, you can contact our support team for a list of phish link domains.
  3. In a separate browser window or tab, log in to the Microsoft 365 Defender portal (https://security.microsoft.com).
  4. Navigate to Email & collaboration > Policies & rules.
  5. Click Threat policies.
  6. Click Safe Links to be taken to the Safe links page.
  7. Select the Link Policy that you created. If you don't have a Link Policy, you'll need to create a new policy by clicking the Create button.
  8. Click Edit protection settings. If you're creating a new policy, navigate to the URL & click protection settings step.
  9. Under Do not rewrite the following URLs in email, click Manage URLs.  
  10. Click + Add URLs.
    Note:Adding phishing simulation URLs to this section might result in unwanted alerts for URL clicks. For more information, Microsoft's article about configurations of advanced delivery policies.
  11. Enter the root domains from your KSAT console. To add the URL, press Enter on your keyboard. 
    Important:Make sure to add each phishing domain using the *.<rootdomain>/* format. For example, if the root domain is "knowbe4.com," you would enter *.knowbe4.com/* into the field.
  12. Once you've entered all of the root domains, click Save.
  13. Click Done.
Note: If phish links are still being rewritten after following the steps above, you may need to disable the Office 365 Apps Safe Links setting. To disable this setting, clear the check box next to On: Safe Links checks a list of known, malicious links when users click links in Microsoft Office apps. URLs are not rewritten.

articles.name: Recording Email Opens in Phishing Security Tests (PSTs)
articles.title: Recording Email Opens in Phishing Security Tests (PSTs)
articles.body:
Your KSAT console records when a user opens a Phishing Security Test (PST) email by using a tracking pixel, which is embedded into all of KnowBe4's PST emails. Upon loading, the pixel will call back to your KSAT console to record if a user has opened their PST email.

Email opens aren't considered a failure on a phishing test and don't contribute to a user's Phish-prone Percentage. A PST will automatically show as opened in certain situations, such as if a user reports the email with the Phish Alert Button (PAB). Additionally, if a user fails your phishing test by clicking a link or opening an attachment, we'll automatically record that email as open in our system, even if the tracking pixel does not load.

Email Opens Not Being Recorded

Some organizations don't allow images in emails to be automatically downloaded. In these cases, email opens can't be tracked because the pixel will not load and won't record the open in PST reports.

If your organization blocks images from being automatically downloaded, there is a method that will allow you to load the tracking pixel and record email opens. See the method below:

Trusted Zone in Outlook

You can create a Group Policy Object (GPO) in Active Directory to update the Trusted Zone in Microsoft Outlook and allow tracking pixels to load without allowing all other PST images to load. The steps to complete this are detailed below:

  1. Navigate to your Domain Group Policy Editor > User Configuration > Windows Settings > Administrative Templates > Windows Components > Internet Explorer > Internet Control Panel > Security Page.
  2. Double-click the Site to Zone Assignment List policy to modify the policy.
  3. Enable the policy by selecting the Enabled option.
  4. Under the Options area, click Show.
  5. From the Show Contents window, enter the phishing link domain used in your test in the Value Name. You can also use wildcards in your entry to indicate a phishing link subdomain.
    • For a complete list of phishing link domains, navigate to the Phishing > Domains tab in your KSAT console. 
  6. For the Value, enter "2", which corresponds to "Trusted Zone". 
  7. Click OK.
Note:Examples from our actual domain list include https://*.phish.farm and https://*.com-token-auth.com.

We recommend sending a phishing test campaign to yourself once these settings are saved so you can ensure opens are being tracked successfully.

Preview Pane Open Tracking

If your mail client is set up to download images in the preview pane automatically, phishing test emails will be marked as opened if your user previews them in the preview pane.

If your mail client doesn't download images automatically in the preview pane, it won't show as opened.

Turn Off Open Tracking

You can turn off email open tracking to remove the embedded tracking pixel so that opens will not be recorded in your PST reports. Follow the steps below if you would like to do that.

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 account.
  2. Click on your email address in the top-right corner and click Account Settings.
  3. Navigate to the Phishing tab, then the Phishing Settings section.
  4. Click the checkbox next to Disable Email Open Tracking.

articles.name: Defend - Quarantine Enablement
articles.title: Defend - Quarantine Enablement
articles.body:
The Defend quarantine feature leverages Microsoft's quarantine to determine what happens when Defend classifies an email as a dangerous phishing email. Quarantining dangerous phishing emails reduces the risk of users having access to click on potentially dangerous links and attachments.

Note:You can now connect KnowBe4 Defend with Microsoft 365 Defender to automatically remediate phishing emails. For more information, see our Defend - Configuring Unified Quarantine with Microsoft Defender for Office 365 article.

The following options are available:

  • Do not send to Microsoft quarantine (default)
    • Enabled by default, emails will not be sent to quarantine but will have appropriate Defend banners attached and delivered to the recipient.
  • Send all phishing emails with an attachment to Microsoft quarantine
    • When enabled, this will quarantine emails classified as dangerous phishing emails that contain an attachment.
  • Send all phishing emails to Microsoft quarantine
    • When enabled, all emails classified as dangerous phishing emails will be sent to quarantine, regardless of attachments.
  • Send high confidence phishing to Microsoft quarantine
    • When enabled, only emails classified as high-confidence phishing will be sent to quarantine.
  • Send high confidence phishing emails with attachments to Microsoft quarantine
    • When enabled, only emails that contain an attachment and are classified as high-confidence phishing emails will be sent to quarantine.
Note:If only highly dangerous phish are sent to quarantine, dangerous phish will be delivered as normal but with the appropriate red banner applied.

To enable the Defend quarantine feature, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Defend console.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Quarantine.
  3. Select the relevant option from the drop-down menu options.

  4. Select Save at the top of the page.
Note:This functionality relies on the Defend Quarantine mail flow rule. If you do not have this rule set, you will see the following message:

Notifications

Since the Defend quarantine process leverages Microsoft's quarantine, this feature does not natively alert or notify when an email has been quarantined. This process is due to the fact that Defend uses a transport rule to send dangerous emails to quarantine. However, should you wish to be alerted, there is an additional Microsoft transport rule you can create, which will create an incident report that alerts an admin or specified address.

Note:When Defend sends an email to quarantine, you will know that Defend did this because the reason field is marked as a transport rule.

To do this action, the additional mail flow rule needed should look like the screenshot below:

User Release Compatibility

Since Defend uses a transport rule to send dangerous emails to quarantine, please note that any user release policies you have in place within Microsoft will not apply. This policy means only admins will be able to release quarantined emails.

Enabling User Notifications and Release Workaround

If you want users to receive notifications about quarantined emails and be able to release messages themselves, you can modify your Defend quarantine rule configuration as listed below:

  1. Change the Defend rule quarantine action
    1. Edit the Defend Quarantine transport rule so that the action is "Set the spam confidence level (SCL) to 9" instead of "Send to Quarantine".
  2. Configure or edit your Microsoft quarantine policy
    1. Ensure you have a Microsoft anti-spam policy that quarantines emails with SCL=9.

articles.name: Custom SecurityTip Topics
articles.title: Custom SecurityTip Topics
articles.body:
When you create a custom SecurityTip, you can assign it a topic. Topics refer to the type of risky behavior the user has done. See the chart below for a complete list of the topics, use cases, and calls to action.

Topic Use Case – Potential Rule Detection
Adult Website A user accessed an adult website on their device. 
Advanced Persistent Threat Unusual activity is detected on a user's device, such as a large volume of files is deleted, sensitive information is collected, command and control behavior are detected, or malware is executed.
Adware Adware is detected on a user's device.
Alcohol / Drug Website A user has accessed an alcohol- or drug-related website on their device. 
Backdoor Malware A user has a computer program on their device that secretly provides a cybercriminal privileged access or unauthorized access to a system.
Bring-Your-Own-Devices A user is using their own device rather than an organized-issued device.
Business Email Compromise A phishing email impersonating or coming from a work-related email account was detected, the user's business email account has been compromised, or CEO fraud was detected.
Cloud Permissions A user misused cloud permissions while sharing documents or files in the cloud.
Copyright Infringement A user visited or downloaded copyright infringement material.
Credential Theft Password theft is detected.
Cryptomining Malware Cryptomining malware is detected on a user's device.
Cryptomining Website A user accessed a cryptomining-related website on their device.
Data Breach Credentials or potentially sensitive data is leaked from a user's device.
Data Security – Encryption A threat is detected on the user's device that requires full disk encryption to mitigate it, or if ransomware encryption activity is detected.
Data Security – Exfiltration There is an unauthorized removal of data or files from a user's device.
Data Security – Sharing A user shared sensitive data externally through email, websites, or shared access to cloud storage.
Data Security – Transfer There is a transfer of sensitive data as files or documents externally through email, websites, or sending through cloud storage functionality.
Dating Website A user accessed a dating website on their device. 
Document Malware A user downloaded a document from their email, which may or may not be malicious.
Email Attachments A user clicked on or downloaded an attachment from an email.
Email Forwarding Email forwarding rules are unusual, unapproved, or sending to an external email.
Email Links A user clicked on a potential malicious link.
Email Safety Out-of-domain email forwarding and suspicious email sending patterns are detected.
Email Spoofing A phishing email impersonating a user was detected.
Endpoint Safety Remote access software was used on the user's device, malicious or suspicious activity or applications were detected, command and control or botnet behavior was detected, or cryptomining malware was detected. 
Exploit Ransomware was found on the user's device, a file or malicious code was found on the user's device that exploits a known vulnerability in either software or on their operating system, or a command and control activity was found on the user's device.
Freeware Freeware or free software is detected on a user's device.
Gambling Website A user accessed a gambling-related website on their device.
Gaming Website A user accessed a gaming-related website on their device.
Insider Threat The activity on the user's device makes it seem that the user may be a security threat to the organization. 
Malware Malware is detected on a user’s device.
Mobile Endpoint Safety Malicious, suspicious activity, or software is detected on the user’s device or a non-compliant device has connected to organizational network.
Mobile Malware Malware has been detected on a mobile device.
Multi-Factor Authentication A user has disabled multi-factor or two-factor authentication, or high severity malicious activity has been detected on the user's device. 
Network Safety A user’s activities have been identified as risky at the network level.
Online Safety A user's browsing activities have been identified as risky.
P2P Website A user accessed a peer-to-peer (P2P)-related website on their device.
Password Safety A broad range of password-related events may have been identified, including if there are multiple failed login attempts; login credentials are accessed, detected, or leaked online as in a data breach; credential theft is detected taken from the user's device; credentials are dumped from the operating system memory or cache; or suspicious login activity is detected. 
Phishing A user interacted with a phishing email.
Pirate Website A user accessed a pirate website on their device. 
Privacy The sharing of personal or financial information was detected, either through email or a website.
Privileged Access A user’s access permissions were detected as being elevated, which can be used to exfiltrate sensitive data or allow a cybercriminal to move through a network.
PUP A potentially unwanted program (PUP) was detected on a user's device.
Ransomware Ransomware is detected on a user's device, or the user downloaded a file from the internet that contains ransomware.
Remote Access Security Remote access software is suspiciously used on a user's device. 
Restricted Website

A user accessed an unidentified restricted website. 

Note:An admin can create a campaign that doesn't specify the type of restricted website that was visited by the user.
Rootkit A computer program was detected on the user's device that secretly provides a cybercriminal privileged access or unauthorized access to a system.
Sensitive Organizational Data A user shared organizational data that shouldn’t be shared.
Sensitive Personal Data A user shared sensitve personal information.
Shareware Shareware is detected on a user's device.
Shopping Website A user accessed a shopping website on their device.
Social Engineering A user fell for social engineering.
Social Website A user accessed a social media website on their device.
Software Security Command and control are detected on the user's device, a vulnerability or exploit is detected, or an external software download is detected.
Spam A user received a spam email or a user is flagged as sending spam messages.
Spyware Spyware is detected on a user's device, or software is downloaded from an external website.
Trojan Horse A trojan is detected on a user's device.
URLs and Hyperlinks A user clicked a malicious URL, hyperlink, or phishing link.
USB Safety Removable media usage is detected or blocked.
Video Streaming Website The user accessed a video streaming website on their device.
Viruses and Worms A virus or worm is detected on a user's device
VPN Best Practices A user connected to a third-party VPN.

articles.name: Malwarebytes Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: Malwarebytes Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Malwarebytes’ endpoint protection (EPP) platform with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by Malwarebytes will be available for use under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Create an OAuth Client

Before you can set up this integration in your KSAT console, you will need to create an OAuth client in your Malwarebytes account.To create an OAuth client in your Malwarebytes account, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Malwarebytes account and navigate to Settings > APIs & Integrations.
  2. Click Add in the top-right corner of the page to open the Create Client window.
  3. Enter the Application name, and select the Read permission.
  4. Click Save to create your client and open the OAuth client window. The OAuth client window displays your Client ID and Client Secret.
  5. Contact Malwarebytes to learn how to obtain your Account ID.
  6. Copy and save your Client ID, Client Secret, and Account ID to somewhere that you can easily access. You will need these items when you complete the integration setup in the Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section below.

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you have created your Malwarebytes OAuth client, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console. To set up the integration, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Malwarebytes and click Configure.
  3. Enter the Client ID, Client Secret, and Account ID in the corresponding fields.
  4. Click Authorize.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Malwarebytes, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Malwarebytes on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

articles.name: Whitelist by Google Safebrowsing in Google Chrome
articles.title: Whitelist by Google Safebrowsing in Google Chrome
articles.body:
Important:Whitelisting by Safe Browsing requires our root Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains. You can access our root Phish Link Domains in your KSAT console, but you must contact KnowBe4 support for an updated list of our Landing Domains. See our What's the Difference Between Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains article for more information.

Domains that are used in our phishing security tests (PSTs) are occasionally flagged by Google Safe Browsing lists, which classify them as malicious, social engineering, phishing, or deceptive login pages. KnowBe4 continuously works to remove these domains from Safe Browsing lists. However, once a domain has been placed on these lists, a warning banner could appear when the link is clicked. The banner may prevent a user from navigating to phishing links or landing pages when they fail a phishing test.

Implementing a Safe Browsing whitelist that includes our phish link domains and landing domains will make sure your users are not presented with warning messages and will allow clicks to report successfully. The Safe Browsing whitelist can be applied across multiple platforms for the Chrome browser, including Windows, macOS, and Chrome-based operating systems.

Requirements for Safe Browsing Whitelisting

These system requirements were obtained from Google Enterprise’s official documentation. For more information, see Google’s Safe Browsing Allowlist Domains article.

For Windows, this functionality is available on the following instances:

  • Instances that are joined to a Microsoft® Active Directory® domain.
  • Instances running on Windows 10 Pro.
  • Instances that are enrolled in Chrome Browser Cloud Management.

For macOS, this functionality is available on the following instances:

  • Instances that are managed via MDM.
  • Instances that are joined to a domain via MCX.

Safe Browsing Whitelisting for Windows

When whitelisting with Safe Browsing on Windows, you will need to use a Group Policy Object (GPO). To apply a bypass on Windows, you will need to implement policy via a GPO for Chrome. See below for instructions on how to apply a bypass.

  1. Download the Chrome ADMX templates. To access these templates, see Google’s Set Chrome Browser policies on managed PCs article and navigate to the Windows section.
  2. Install the ADMX templates on the domain controller. The ADMX templates will then be available to assign via GPO.
  3. Within the GPO Editor, navigate to Computer Configuration → Administrative Templates → Google → Google Chrome → Safe Browsing Settings → Configure the list of domains on which Safe Browsing will not trigger warnings.
  4. Within the setting configuration, select Enabled. Then, select Show to see the list for configuration.
  5. Add the root domains of the phish link and landing domains that are used in your PSTs. Domains are listed using the syntax: example.com
  6. Click OK, then click Apply.
  7. Click OK again.

Once you restart your Chrome browser, navigate to Chrome://Policy to verify the policy was installed successfully.

Safe Browsing Whitelisting for macOS

To push the whitelisting policy on macOS, you will need to edit any existing Google Chrome .plist files that are pushed to your machines. The edited .plist files will need the entries listed in Step 2 below. A new policy can also be created to push via MDM solutions. See below for instructions on both of these procedures.

  1. Create a .plist file and open it in the editor of your choice. You can use the sample file attached here: Sample File
  2. Edit the entries in the .plist file to list the Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains that are used in your PSTs. Each root domain is a <string> entry in the <array>, which is listed under the <key>Safe BrowsingAllowlistDomains</key> entry.
  3. Save the .plist file and use a converter, such as mcxToProfile, to convert this file into a system policy.
  4. Deploy the policy to the machine via MDM.

Once you restart your Chrome browser, navigate to Chrome://Policy to verify the policy was installed successfully.

Safe Browsing Whitelisting for Chrome Profile

To push the whitelisting policy on machines managed by Chrome, or Chrome-based devices, you will need to edit the following settings in your Google administrator console:

  1. Open your Google Admin portal.
  2. Navigate to Devices → Chrome → Settings → Users & browsers → Safe browsing allowed domains.
  3. Enter the root domains of the Phish Link Domains and Landing Domains that are used in your PSTs. Please enter one domain per line.
  4. Click Save.

Navigate to Chrome://Policy to verify the policy was installed successfully. This policy is locally applied to the browser or machine depending on your existing Chrome management configuration.

For further assistance with this feature, please contact our support team and they will be happy to help.

articles.name: Set Up Your Account’s Time Zone, Business Days, and Hours
articles.title: Set Up Your Account’s Time Zone, Business Days, and Hours
articles.body:
You can edit your Account Settings to include a default time zone for your account, as well as business days and hours. Setting a time zone, business days, and hours on your account will automatically populate this information when you set up a phishing campaign. On a training campaign, your default time zone will also automatically populate.

To change your default settings, follow the instructions below:

articles.name: Integrate Secureframe with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.title: Integrate Secureframe with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.body:
In this article, you’ll learn how to integrate your Secureframe account with your KSAT console. This integration allows you to automate your compliance training by automatically sending your KSAT training data to your Secureframe account.

Note:Before you set up this integration, you'll need to copy the Reporting API Token from your KSAT Account Settings page. For more information, see the API section of our KSAT Account Settings: Account Integrations article.

To learn how to integrate your KSAT console with your Secureframe account, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Secureframe account.
  2. From the navigation bar on the left side of the page, select Integrations.
  3. On the Available Integrations page, search for KnowBe4.
  4. Click Connect.
  5. On the KnowBe4 connection page, paste your Reporting API Token.
  6. Select your KnowBe4 training instance.
  7. Click Submit.
  8. From the navigation bar on the left side of the page, select Personnel.
  9. Select the Onboarding tab, then scroll down to the Training section.
  10. Select KnowBe4 in each applicable Vendor drop-down menu. You can mix and match training vendors across the different training fields.
  11. In each area where KnowBe4 is the assigned vendor, select one or more campaigns in the Campaigns drop-down menus. Inactive campaigns can’t be selected.
  12. From the navigation bar on the left side of the page, select Tests.
  13. Click the Evidence tab.
  14. Select each corresponding test.
  15. Click the three dots icon, then select Refresh test.

Once the connection is established, you’ll be able to see your KSAT integration in the Integrations section of your Secureframe account.

articles.name: Discontinuing the Vishing Feature
articles.title: Discontinuing the Vishing Feature
articles.body:
As of January 1, 2023, we have discontinued our vishing feature.

Why Is Vishing Discontinued?

We have discontinued our vishing feature for the best interest of our users. Due to the recent increase in vishing scams, telecommunication carriers have developed stricter policies and updated their terms of service to prevent vishing scams. These policies do not differentiate between simulated vishing tests and real vishing attacks, which use similar tactics. As our simulated vishing tests are no longer compliant with these policies, using this feature could result in legal penalties for our users. We have discontinued our vishing feature to continue providing a safe and educational user experience.

How Can I Continue to Train My Users on Vishing?

To continue training your users on vishing, we recommend creating training campaigns that include vishing training content.

To help you get started, see the list of training content that includes training on vishing below:
